title: Troubleshooting
text: encounter warning “Model failed converge max|grad|” fitting model lmm(), one common cause poor scaling time variable. simple effective fix rescale time larger unit (example, days months). Using melanoma2 dataset, following code produces convergence warning: case, converting time days months resolves convergence issue. , create new time variable dividing average number days per month, update tumr object, refit model: rescaling time variable, model fits without producing convergence warning. Rescaling time can improve numerical stability optimization, making easier model converge—especially time values large measured fine scale.
code: data(melanoma2) mel2 <- tumr(melanoma2, ID, Day, Volume, Treatment) lmm(mel2) Warning in checkConv(attr(opt, "derivs"), opt$par, ctrl = control$checkConv, : Model failed to converge with max|grad| = 0.00566844 (tol = 0.002, component 1)   See ?lme4::convergence and ?lme4::troubleshooting. title: Troubleshooting
text: case, converting time days months resolves convergence issue. , create new time variable dividing average number days per month, update tumr object, refit model: rescaling time variable, model fits without producing convergence warning.
code: melanoma2$months <- melanoma2$Day / (365/12) mel2 <- tumr(melanoma2, ID, months, Volume, Treatment) lmm(mel2) Linear mixed model fit by REML. t-tests use Satterthwaite's method [ lmerModLmerTest] Formula: log1p(Volume) ~ Treatment * months + (months | ID)    Data: data  REML criterion at convergence: 1182.4  Scaled residuals:     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max -6.8683 -0.3590  0.0569  0.4891  4.0759  Random effects:  Groups   Name        Variance Std.Dev. Corr  ID       (Intercept) 0.3911   0.6254           months      0.6025   0.7762   -0.51  Residual             0.3221   0.5675 Number of obs: 568, groups:  ID, 47  Fixed effects:                   Estimate Std. Error      df t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept)         3.6609     0.2269 46.8170  16.134  < 2e-16 *** TreatmentB          0.5383     0.3226 42.8852   1.669  0.10244 TreatmentC          0.7805     0.3196 46.0697   2.442  0.01849 * TreatmentD          1.3329     0.3241 48.7024   4.112  0.00015 *** TreatmentE         -0.1469     0.3320 42.4100  -0.443  0.66031 months              2.4245     0.2729 47.8797   8.885 1.07e-11 *** TreatmentB:months  -1.2083     0.3860 43.3477  -3.130  0.00312 ** TreatmentC:months  -0.8130     0.3818 46.2297  -2.129  0.03861 * TreatmentD:months  -0.7594     0.4018 54.1899  -1.890  0.06412 . TreatmentE:months  -0.9309     0.3953 42.1808  -2.355  0.02327 * --- Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1  Correlation of Fixed Effects:             (Intr) TrtmnB TrtmnC TrtmnD TrtmnE months TrtmB: TrtmC: TrtmD: TreatmentB  -0.703 TreatmentC  -0.710  0.499 TreatmentD  -0.700  0.492  0.497 TreatmentE  -0.683  0.481  0.485  0.478 months      -0.577  0.406  0.410  0.404  0.395 TrtmntB:mnt  0.408 -0.560 -0.290 -0.286 -0.279 -0.707 TrtmntC:mnt  0.413 -0.290 -0.573 -0.289 -0.282 -0.715  0.505 TrtmntD:mnt  0.392 -0.276 -0.278 -0.586 -0.268 -0.679  0.480  0.485 TrtmntE:mnt  0.398 -0.280 -0.283 -0.279 -0.556 -0.690  0.488  0.493  0.469

title: Troubleshooting
text: Rescaling time can improve numerical stability optimization, making easier model converge—especially time values large measured fine scale.

what: Putting lmm() Summary Plot on the Log Scale
title: Troubleshooting
text: viewing summary plot lmm(), may see message: “Model log1p-transformed response. Back-transforming predictions original response scale.Standard errors still transformed scale.” message appears lmm() fits model using log1p-transformed response default, plot() method automatically back-transforms predicted values original response scale. prefer view predicted volume values log scale, can apply log transformation directly plot’s y-axis. Since summary plot ggplot2 object, can done using scale_y_continuous() log1p transformation scales package.  approach preserves model fit allowing visualize predictions uncertainty transformed scale.
code: lmm_mel2 <- lmm(mel2) plot(lmm_mel2)$predicted_measure + ggplot2::scale_y_continuous(trans = scales::log1p_trans()) Model has log1p-transformed response. Back-transforming predictions to   original response scale. Standard errors are still on the transformed   scale. Scale for y is already present. Adding another scale for y, which will replace the existing scale.

title: Troubleshooting
text: lmm() function allows override default model formula, providing flexibility fitting alternative model specifications. default, lmm() fits model form log1p(measure) ~ group * time + (time | id) (example, Volume ~ months + (1 | ID)). example , default formula replaced simpler model uses rescaled time variable random intercept : model fits successfully, calling summary() object fail. occurs summary() method designed around default lmm() model structure currently assumes formula. result, alternative formulas may fully supported summary(). using custom formula, keep mind downstream methods—summary()—may behave expected.
code: lmm_mel2 <- lmm(                  tumr_obj = mel2,                  formula = "Volume ~ months + (1 | ID)"                )

title: Getting started with the tumr package
Getting started with the tumr package
text: introducing tumr functionality, first construct simple plotting function illustrate common pitfall tumor growth visualization. Note: plot_mean() part tumr package. defined solely provide baseline visualization comparison tumr’s methods.
code: plot_mean <- function(data, group, time, measure, id, stat = median, remove_na = FALSE){   data_summary <- data |>     dplyr::group_by({{group}}, {{time}}) |>     dplyr::summarise(measure = stat({{measure}}, na.rm = remove_na), .groups = "drop_last") |>     dplyr::ungroup()    if (remove_na == TRUE) {     data_full <- data |>       na.omit(data)   } else {     data_full <- data   }    ggplot2::ggplot() +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_full,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = {{measure}},                                     group = {{id}},                                     color = {{group}}),                        alpha = 0.5)  +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_summary,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = measure,                                     color = {{group}}),                        linewidth = 1.2) +     ggplot2::labs(             y = "Volume",             title = "Volume over Time"           )  }

title: Getting started with the tumr package
text: Note: plot_mean() part tumr package. defined solely provide baseline visualization comparison tumr’s methods.
code: plot_mean <- function(data, group, time, measure, id, stat = median, remove_na = FALSE){   data_summary <- data |>     dplyr::group_by({{group}}, {{time}}) |>     dplyr::summarise(measure = stat({{measure}}, na.rm = remove_na), .groups = "drop_last") |>     dplyr::ungroup()    if (remove_na == TRUE) {     data_full <- data |>       na.omit(data)   } else {     data_full <- data   }    ggplot2::ggplot() +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_full,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = {{measure}},                                     group = {{id}},                                     color = {{group}}),                        alpha = 0.5)  +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_summary,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = measure,                                     color = {{group}}),                        linewidth = 1.2) +     ggplot2::labs(             y = "Volume",             title = "Volume over Time"           )  }

title: Getting started with the tumr package
text: tumr functions operate tumr object, stores data associated metadata (subject ID, time, outcome, grouping variable). create tumr object, use tumr() function: object can now passed directly tumr functions.
code: mel2 <- tumr(melanoma2, ID, Day, Volume, Treatment)

title: Getting started with the tumr package
text: figure compares naive longitudinal visualization tumr-based approach explicitly accounts censoring missing observations.   plot left uses straightforward summary observed data time point. approach ignores structure missingness common tumor growth studies, subjects frequently leave study due censoring dropout. result, apparent decline tumor volume time artifact estimating summaries progressively smaller subset subjects rather true biological effect. visualization produced plot_median() addresses issues explicit preprocessing step designed longitudinal tumor data. summary statistic computed, function: Aligns time points across subjects Rows added unobserved time points subjects share common time grid. Handles trailing missing values due censoring last observed value carried forward marked “+” indicate right-censoring. Example: 3, 6, 9, NA → 3, 6, 9, 9+ Interpolates embedded missing values Missing observations occur recorded time points interpolated preserve trajectory continuity. preprocessing, tumor volume summaries computed time point within treatment group using Kaplan–Meier–based approach. strategy ensures summaries reflect observed data informative missingness, producing visualization accurately represents tumor growth dynamics time.
code: plot_mean(melanoma2, Treatment, Day, Volume, ID, stat = mean) plot_median(mel2)

title: Getting started with the tumr package
text: One primary analysis tools tumr rfeat() function, implements response feature analysis. two-stage approach simplifies complex longitudinal data extracting single interpretable summary measure per subject. Specifically, rfeat(): Computes growth slope (beta coefficient) subject Averages slopes within treatment group Compares group-level summaries using one following methods: t-test ANOVA Tukey post-hoc test ANOVA Tukey post-hoc tests example uses comparison = “” perform ANOVA followed Tukey post-hoc comparisons. plot() method rfeat objects displays individual subject slopes group-level means.

title: Getting started with the tumr package
text: plot() method rfeat objects displays individual subject slopes group-level means.

title: Getting started with the tumr package
text: tumr package also includes lmm(), fits linear mixed effects model tumor growth data. Linear mixed models well suited longitudinal data account : Fixed effects: population-level effects interest (e.g., treatment, time) Random effects: subject-specific variability induces correlation among repeated measurements default, lmm() fits model: log1p(measure) ~ group * time + (time | id) specification allows subject growth trajectory estimating overall treatment effects. model formula can customized desired. Note: may see convergence warning fitting model. occurs, see Troubleshooting article guidance. summary() method lmm objects uses emmeans package report: overall effect time Treatment-specific slopes time Statistical tests comparing slope differences groups Finally, tumr provides plot() method lmm objects produces two visualizations: Predicted tumor growth trajectories time Estimated mean growth slopes group confidence intervals
code: (lmm_mel2 <- lmm(mel2)) Warning in checkConv(attr(opt, "derivs"), opt$par, ctrl = control$checkConv, : Model failed to converge with max|grad| = 0.00566844 (tol = 0.002, component 1)   See ?lme4::convergence and ?lme4::troubleshooting. Corr  ID       (Intercept) 0.3909753 0.62528           Day         0.0006511 0.02552  -0.51  Residual             0.3220706 0.56751 Number of obs: 568, groups:  ID, 47  Fixed effects:                Estimate Std. title: Getting started with the tumr package
text: Finally, tumr provides plot() method lmm objects produces two visualizations: Predicted tumor growth trajectories time Estimated mean growth slopes group confidence intervals
code: plot(lmm_mel2) Model has log1p-transformed response. Back-transforming predictions to   original response scale. Standard errors are still on the transformed   scale. $predicted_measure $mean_betas

title: Getting started with the tumr package
text: addition linear mixed model, package also supports Bayesian hierarchical linear model. subject treatment group g, outcome time t_n modeled y_n \sim \mathcal{N}\big(\beta_{,1} + \beta_{,2} t_n,\ \sigma\big), subject-specific intercepts slopes follow hierarchical structure: \begin{pmatrix} \beta_{,1} \\ \beta_{,2} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \text{Int}_g \\ \text{Slope}_g \end{pmatrix} + L z_i, \qquad z_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0, ). , \text{Int}_g \text{Slope}_g denote treatment-level mean intercepts slopes, L Cholesky factor random-effect covariance matrix. Weakly informative normal priors assigned treatment-level effects variance components, LKJ prior correlation structure. summary() method provides posterior summaries : Treatment-specific intercepts exponential transformation Treatment-specific slopes exponential transformation Pairwise treatment contrasts slopes exponential transformation Posterior means credible intervals reported quantities. plot() method visualizes posterior summaries, including: Treatment-specific slope estimates 90% credible intervals Pairwise slope contrasts Optional MCMC trace plots model diagnostics

title: Getting started with the tumr package
text: summary() method provides posterior summaries : Treatment-specific intercepts exponential transformation Treatment-specific slopes exponential transformation Pairwise treatment contrasts slopes exponential transformation Posterior means credible intervals reported quantities.

title: Getting started with the tumr package
text: plot() method visualizes posterior summaries, including: Treatment-specific slope estimates 90% credible intervals Pairwise slope contrasts Optional MCMC trace plots model diagnostics

title: Authors and Citation
text: Patrick Breheny. Author, maintainer. Sydney Plowman. Author. Tian Zhao. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Breheny P, Plowman S, Zhao T (2026). tumr: Analysis Power Calculations Tumor Growth Rates. R package version 0.5.1, https://pbreheny.github.io/tumr/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {tumr: Analysis and Power Calculations for Tumor Growth Rates},   author = {Patrick Breheny and Sydney Plowman and Tian Zhao},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.5.1},   url = {https://pbreheny.github.io/tumr/}, }

what: Analysis and Power Calculations for Tumor Growth Rates
title: Analysis and Power Calculations for Tumor Growth Rates
text: tumr collection tools analyzing tumor growth data. example use tumr can seen Get Started page. tumr includes: tumr() - creates tumr object can passed plot_median(), rfeat(), lmm(). plot_median() - creates spaghetti plot plots median tumor growth measurement treatment group. rfeat() - tests whether beta coefficients (slope tumor measure time) individuals different treatment groups different using either t-test, ANOVA, Tukey, ANOVA Tukey. rfeat() plot() function shows individual beta coefficients mean slope treatment group. lmm() - fits linear mixed model default formula log1p(Volume) ~ Treatment * scale(Day) + (scale(Day) | ID) time variable centered. lmm() includes summary() function provides overall effect time averaged levels treatment group, slope treatment time treatment group, results contrast test slope differences treatment groups. lmm() includes plot() function shows predicted values tumor growth measurements time mean slope treatment 95% confidence intervals.

title: Analysis and Power Calculations for Tumor Growth Rates
text: install tumr, copy paste following code console

title: Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
text: n Number mice per group effect_size Vector effect sizes, growth ratio (default: 2) m Number measurements per mouse (default: 3) alpha Shape parameter gamma distribution (default: 9) sd Noise (standard deviation, default: 100)

title: Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
text: Y            Observed measurements M            Idealized 'true' size mouse time (error) B            'True' growth rate mouse (data-generating mechanism)

title: Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
code: Data <- gendat(5, effect_size=2, m=6) matplot(Data$time, t(Data$Y[,,1]), lty=1, type='l', col='#FF4E37', bty='n', las=1,         ylab=expression("Tumor volume "*(mm^3)), xlab='Day') matplot(Data$time, t(Data$Y[,,2]), lty=1, type='l', col='#008DFF', add=TRUE)

what: Creates plots for a bhm object — plot.bhm
title: Creates plots for a bhm object — plot.bhm
text: Produces interval plots treatment-specific slopes, slope contrasts, MCMC trace plots based posterior summaries returned summary().

title: Creates plots for a bhm object — plot.bhm
code: # S3 method for class 'bhm' plot(x, type = c("slope", "contrast", "trace"), ...)

title: Creates plots for a bhm object — plot.bhm
text: x bhm object returned bhm(). type Character string specifying plot produce. One "slope", "contrast", "trace". ... arguments passed trace plotting functions (currently used type = "trace").

title: Creates plots for a bhm object — plot.bhm
text: type "slope" "contrast", returns ggplot object. type "trace", returns list ggplot objects elements trace_intercept, trace_slope, trace_slope_diff.

title: Creates plots for a bhm object — plot.bhm
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data("melanoma1") fit <- bhm(melanoma1) p1 <- plot(fit, type = "slope") p2 <- plot(fit, type = "contrast") p3 <- p2 + ggplot2::scale_x_continuous(transform = "exp", labels = function(z) sprintf("%.2f", exp(z))) plot(fit, type = "trace") p3 } # }

title: Analysis based on response features — rfeat
text: tumr_obj takes tumr_obj created tumr() data gendat id Column subject ID's time Column repeated time measurements measure Column repeated measurements tumor group Column specifying treatment group measurement log log transformation measurement using log1p comparison Takes "t.test", "anova", "tukey", ""

title: Analysis based on response features — rfeat
text: p-value

title: Analysis based on response features — rfeat
code: data(breast) rfeat( data = breast, id = "ID", time = "Week", measure = "Volume", group = "Treatment", comparison = "t.test") #>  #> 	Welch Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  Beta by Group #> t = 0.64605, df = 24.351, p-value = 0.5243 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group NR and group VEH is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.3345751  0.6398147 #> sample estimates: #>  mean in group NR mean in group VEH  #>         0.8872739         0.7346541  #>  data(melanoma1) rfeat( data = melanoma1, id = "ID", time = "Day", measure = "Volume", group = "Treatment", comparison = "anova") #>             Df  Sum Sq  Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)     #> Group        3 0.04132 0.013775    26.4 1.13e-08 *** #> Residuals   31 0.01618 0.000522                      #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1
